references.title: Low proportion of disabled people entering higher education. Press Release.
references.raw: SKILL. (2002) Low proportion of disabled people entering higher education. Press Release. London, UK. 30 th September (http://www.skill.org.uk/press/archives/30092002.asp). Chart 1: Movement through the education system for the RITE study transition group (n=15) Mainstream secondary school N = 7 Mainstream and special needs secondary schools N = 3 Mainstream Further Education College N = 8 Mainstream and Special Needs Further Education College N = 4 Special Needs Education College N = 3 University N = 4 Special Needs school N = 5 Employment One of the four who had finished education was in paid part-time work and one worked as a part-time volunteer. Three people still in education worked part-time: a communications and disability consultant; an IT technician and policy coordinator, and a sessional play worker working full-time during the summer holidays. Chart 2: Movement through the education system for the RITE study post-transition group (n=15) Mainstream/LSU and Special Needs secondary school N = 3 Special Needs Day School N = 8 Mainstream Further Education College N = 7 Mainstream and Special Needs Further Education College N = 4 University N = 6 + 1 Distance Learning N = 2 3 f-t students and one p-t student Special Needs Education College N = 4 Special Needs Residential School N = 4 Employment Five people were employed full-time. The two who were paid earned £20,000-30,000 and £50,000-75,000 pa. Six people worked part-time, three were paid and earned less than £5,000 pa.
